DIV1.P: THE MAID OF BATH, A COMEDY, OF THREE ACTS, As it is performed at the THEATRE-ROYAL, in the Hay-Market.
WITH THE ORIGINAL PROLOGUE, As written By Mr. GARRICK, And spoken By Mr. FOOTE; The EPILOGUE, spoken by Mrs. JEWELL.
LONDON: PRINTED for GEORGE ALLEN, No. 59; Pater-Noster Row.

DIV1.HEAD: TO SAMUEL FOOTE, Esq.
DIV1.P:
THE very ungentleman-like treatment you have experienced from the avariciousness and personal envy of the managers of both hou∣ses, in mutilating your plays and changing them into farces, determined you, long since, to sup∣press the publication of any future production. With an eye of pity you beheld the sordid views and ungenerous dispositions of Mr. C. and Mr. G. A species of dramatic writing they never could attain to, prompted them to injure you in in the nicest and most sensible manner, that of profitting by the labour and invention of a Gen∣tleman, whose abilities, as actor and performer, could support the expences of a theatre at a time, when with all their ingenuity and pageantry, they
are under absolute necessity of shutting up their houses.
FROM these motives, the Public had to regret the loss of those pieces which do the greatest honor to your literary merit.

ONE objection, only, was raised to this pub∣lication of the MAID OF BATH, viz. That whilst the Publisher rail'd at the avariciousness of others, he might be condemn'd for covetousness and un∣generous treatment himself.

BUT the case is materially different. As you never intended to benefit yourself by a publica∣tion, no injury can be done you by its being published by another hand. In short, Sir, could the least injury accrue, no one would be more ready to forego every advantage; but whilst the contrary is manifestly the case, you and the world will excuse me for giving them the perusal of a piece which they have long lamented as buried in oblivion; especially those who never could have an opportunity of seeing the performance.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE,
DIV1.BYLINE: Written by D. GARRICK, Esq. And spoken by Mr. FOOTE.
DIV1.L: WHO but has read, if he can read at all,
Of one, they Jack the Giant-killer call:
He was a bold, stout, able-bodied man,
To clear the world of fee, faw, fum, his plan.
Whene'er a monster had within his power
A young and tender virgin to devour,
To cool his blood, Jack, like a skilful surgeon,
Bled well the monster and releas'd the virgin:
Like the best doctors, did a method learn
Of curing fevers,—never to return.
Mayn't I this Giant-killing trade renew?
I have my virgin, and my monster too.
Though I can't boast, like Jack, a list of slain,
I wield a lancet, and can breathe a vein;
To his Herculean arm my nerves are weak,
He cleft his foes, I only make mine squeak;
As Indians wound their slaves to please the court,
I'll tickle mine, great sirs, to make you sport.
To prove myself an humble imitator,
Giants are vices, and Jack stands for satire:
By tropes and figures, as it fancy suits,
Passions rise monsters, men sink down to brutes;
All talk and write in allegorick diction,
Court, city, town and country, run to fiction!
Each daily paper allegory teaches—
Placemen are locusts, and contractors leeches;
Nay e'en Change-Alley, where no bard repairs,
Deals much in fiction to pass off their wares;
Else whence that roaring there?—From bulls and bears?
The gaming fools are doves, the knaves are rooks,
Change-Alley bankrupts waddle out lame ducks!
But, Ladies, blame not your gaming spouses,
For you, as well as they, have pidgeon-houses!
To change the figure—formerly I've been
To straggling follies only whipper-in;
By royal bounty rais'd, I mount the back
Of my own hunter, and I lead the Pack;
Tallyho!—a rank old fox we now pursue,
So strong the scent, you'll run him full in view;
If we can't kill such brutes in human shape,
Let's fright 'em, that your chickens may escape;
Rouse em, when o'er their tender prey they're grumbling,
And rub their gums, at least to mar their mumb∣ling.

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: WHY, John, Roger, Ralphy; what a dickens are become of all the lads; can't you hear? Zure, zure, these whelps are enow to make a man maz'd.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Coming sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: Coming! ay zo be Christmas I think. Where bee'st thee a running boy? What, I reckon, thee cannot zee for thy eyes; here, take the candle and light the gentlefolk in.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Carry a couple of candles into the Daphne.

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: John, who is it be come?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Major Racket, in a chay and four, from the Devizes.

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: What, the young youth that last zeason carry'd away wi un Mrs. Muzlinses prentice?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Miss Patty Prim, from the Grove.

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: Ay zure, thee dost know her well enough.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: The same.

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: Zure, zure, then we shall have old doings anon; he is a deadly wild spark among the wenches thee dost know.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: But as good a customer as comes to the Bear.

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: That's zure enough; then why dost not run and light en in. Stay, gi I the candle: its best for the maister to do't himself, thee dost know.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Give the post boys half a guinea between 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P:
Ay, there is some life in this chap, these are your guests that give spirit to Bath: your parylitical people that come down to be parboil'd and pump'd do no good, that I know, to the town, unless indeed to the physical tribe.—How
I hate to see an old fellow hobble into the house, with his feet wrap'd in flannel, pushing forth his ossify'd fingers like a cross on the hands to point out the different roads on a common:—hush—

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: I hope you do zee your way; there be two steps you do know: well, zure, I be heartily glad to zee your honor at Bath.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: I thank you, my honest friend Fillup; what have you many people in town?

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: There be'nt a power, please your honor, at present. Zome zick folk that do no sort of zarvis, and a few lawyers that be com'd of a the zircuit.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Birds of passage, hey Fillup?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: True, Sir, for at the begining of term, when the woodcocks come in, these others fly off.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: What, are you there honest Jack?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: And happy to see your honor in town.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Well, master Fillup, and how go you on; any clubs fix'd as yet?

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: No zir, not to zay fix'd; there be parzon Pulruddock from Land's End, master Evan Tho∣mas a Welch Attorney, two Bristol men, and a few port drinking people that dine every day in the Lyon; the claret club be'nt expected down till the end of next week.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Any body in the house that I know?

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: Ay zure, behind the bar there be Sir Christopher Cripple, fresh out of a fit of the gout, tossing off a sneaker of punch along wi master Peter Poultice the Potter-carrier on the parade.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: The gazettes of the Bath, the very men that I want. Give my compliments to the gen∣tlemen, and tell them I should be glad of their company; but perhaps it may be troublesome for Sir Christopher—

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: No, no. At present he is a little tender for zure, but I warrant un he'll make a shift to hobble into the room.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Well Jack, and how fares it with you? you have throve, I hope, since I saw you.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Throve, no, no Sir, your honor knows that during the summer, taverns and turnspits have but little to do at the Bath.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: True, but what is become of your col∣league, honest Ned, I hope he has not quitted his place?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: The share he had in your honors in∣trigue with Miss Prim, soon made this city too hot for poor Ned.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Then why did not the fool follow me to London? The fellow has humour, spirit, and sings a good song. I intended to have recom∣mended him to one of the theatres.

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: Why, Sir, Ned himself had a bias that way; but his uncle, Mr. Alderman Surcingle, a sadler, and a peice of a puritan, would not give his consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Why not?

SP.SPEAKER: John.
SP.P: He was afraid that kind of life might corrupt or endanger Neds morals,—so he set him up in a bagnio at the end of Long Acre.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Nay, if the fellow falls after such a se∣curity—
SP.STAGE: Enter Sir CHRISTOPHER CRIPPLE, led in by FILLUP and PETER POULTICE.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: At what a rate the rascal is running; zounds, I believe the fellow thinks I can foot it as fast as Eclipse A noted running horse of the famous Count O' Kelly's.; slower and be—Where is this rake helly rantapole—Jack set me a chair. So, Sir, you must possess a good share of assu∣rance to return to this town after the tricks you have play'd. Fillup, fetch in the punch; well you ungracious young dog, and what's become of the wench? Poor Patty! and here too my re∣putation is ruin'd as well as the girls.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Your reputation, that's a good jest!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P:
Yes, Sirrah, it is, and all owing to my acquaintance with you. I, forsooth, am call'd your
adviser; as if your own contriving head, and pro∣fligate heart, stood in need of any assistance from me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Well, but my dear Sir Kitt, how can this idle stuff affect you?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: How! Easy enough. I'll be judg'd by Poultice; Peter speak truth, before this here blot in my scutheon, have not you observ'd when I went to either a ball, or a breakfasting, how eagerly all the girls gathered round me, gibing and joking, and gigling, gad take me, as facetious and free as if I was their father.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Nothing but truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: That's truth, to my zertain knowledge, I have zeen the women folk titering 'till they were ready to split, when your honor was a throwing your double taunders For double entendres. about.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Right, Fillup; and tho' now and then a prudish slut would prim up her mouth when I gave her a sly stroke, yet the worst word that ever I got was, ah, you are a horrid wild toad; by what you are, one may guess what you have been!

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: Except it be Seignior Trillins, the vamous foreign fine singer, his honor was the greatest favorite among the quality that ever I zeed. As pretty and severe a sarcasm on the nobilities encou∣raging of Italian eunuchs, and insipid signoras, as ever came from the pen of Mr. Foote.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: True, honest Fillup,—before your curs'd affair, neither maid, widow, or wife, was ashamed of conversing with me; but now, when I am wheel'd into the room, not a soul under seventy will venture within ten yards of my chair. I am shunn'd worse than a leper in the days of king Lud; an absolute hermit in the midst of a croud: speak, Fillup, is not this a melancholy truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: Very mollycolly zure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: But this is not all. The crop-ear'd curs of the City have taken it into their empty heads to neglect me; formerly Mr. Mayor could not devour a custard, but I receiv'd a civil card to partake; but now the rude rascals, in their bushy bobs, brush by me without deigning to bow; in short, I don't believe I have had a cor∣poration-crust in my mouth for these six months—you might as well expect to meet a minister of state at the mansion-house, This alludes to the majority of patriots in Alderman Beckford's mayralty, and perfectly expressive of the present one. as see me at one of their feasts.

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: His honor tells nothing but truth.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Oh, Tom, Tom, you have been a curs'd acquaintance to me; what a number of fine turtle and fat haunches of venison has your wickedness lost me!

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: My dear Sir Kitt, for this I merit your thanks; how often has Doctor Carawitchet told you, that your rich food, and champaign would produce nothing but poor health and real pain.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: What signifies the prattle of such a punning puppy as he; what, I suppose, you would starve me you scoundrel! when I am got out of one fit how the devil am I to gather strength to encounter the next. Do you think it is to be done by sipping, and slopping? But no matter,—look you, Major Racket, all between us is now at end; and, Sir, I should consider it as a par∣ticular favor if you would take no farther notice of me; I sincerely desire to drop your acquain∣tance: and as to myself, I am fix'd, positively fixed, to reform.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Reform, ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Reform! And why not? Well, you shall see, the whole city shall see; as soon as ever I get to my lodgings I will send for Luke Latitat and codicil a handsome bequest to the hospital.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Stuff.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Then I am resolved to be carried every day to the twelve a clock prayers at the abbey, and regularly twice of a Sunday; damn me if I will not. A just character of a debilitated superannuated valetu∣dinarian.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! You may laugh; but, if all this don't recover my credit, I am determin'd, besides, to hire a house in Harlequin Row, and be a constant hearer at the Countess's Chapel. Meaning the Countess Dowager of Hunt—don, who has a chapel at Bath. Mr. Whitefield was her chap∣lain. And Harlequin Row hints at Mr. Woodward's having been the best harlequin in this kingdom.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: And so, perhaps, turn out a field preacher in time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: I don't know but I may.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Well then, my dear Sir Christopher, adieu; but, if we must part, let us part as friends should do, not with dry lips and in anger. Fillup, take care of the Knight. [Fillup fills the glasses] Well, faith, my old crony, I can't say but I am heartily sorry to lose you; many a brave batch have we broach'd in our time.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: True, Tom, true.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Don't you remember the bout we had at the Tuns in the days of plump Jack? I shall never forget; after you had fell'd poor Falstaff by a pint bumper of Burgundy, how you bestrode the prostrate hero, and in his own manner cry'd, “Crown me ye spirits that delight in generous wine!”

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Vanity, mere vanity, Tom; nothing but vanity!

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: And then another day at the—but replenish; Fillup, the Bowl is not empty.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Enough, enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: What! don't flinch man, it is but to finish the—Come, Sir Christopher, one tender squeeze—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Take care of my hand; none of your old tricks you young dog.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Gentle as the lick of a lap-dog, there—(shaking hands) What a clock is it Fillup?

SP.SPEAKER: Phli.
SP.P: Just turn'd a six.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: So soon! hang it, Sir Kitt, it is too early to part; come, what say you to one supper more? But one, by way of sacrifice to the sacred feelings of friendship. Honest Fillup knows your taste, he'll toss you up a—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Not a morsel, Tom, if you would give me the universe.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Pooh, man, only a Sandwich or so. Fillup, what has't got in the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: A famous Jahn Dory, two pair of soles; and there be a joint of Clarkendown mutton.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: A fine bill of fare—Come, knight, what do you choose?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Me? Why you seem to have forgot what I told you just now.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack
SP.P:
Your design to reform? Not at all, and I think you quite right, perfectly so, as I hope to be sav'd; but what needs all this hurry? To∣morrow
is a new day, it will then be early enough. Fillup, send us in just what you will.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Ah, you are a coaxing, cajoling, young dog. Well, if it must be so, Fillup, it must;—Fillup, get me an anchovy toast; and, do you hear? A red herring or two, for my stomach is so damnably weak.

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: I shall to be zure.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: So that is settled; now Poultice come forward,—Well, my blades, and what news have you stiring among you?

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Except a little run of fore throats about the beginning of autumn, and a few feeble fellows who dropp'd off with the leaves in October, the town is in tolerable—

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Pox of the dead and the dying; what amusements have you got for the living? As to the musical world, what hopes have we there? Any of the opera people amongst you? Apropos, What is become of my little flame La Petite Rossignole, the lovely little Linnet, is she still—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Lost, totally lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Lost! What, left you? I am sorry for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Worse, worse!

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: I hope she an't dead!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Ten thousand times worse than all that!

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: How the deuce can that be?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Just going to be buryed alive,—to be married!

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Pooh, is that all; that ceremony was in∣deed formerly look'd upon as a kind of metapho∣rical grave; but the system is changed, and mar∣riage is now considered as a resurection The word, resurection, was objected to by the Lord Chamberlain, when the play was presented for his Lordship's approbation; and Mr. Foote chang'd it into entrance. An alteration that does equal honor to the Chamberlain and the Author. to a new and better kind of life.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Pshaw! who talks now of the drudgery of domestic duties, of nuptial chains and of bonds! Mere obsolete words! they did well enough in the dull days of queen Bess. But a modern lass puts on fetters to enjoy the more freedom, and pledges her faith to one, that she may be at liberty to bestow her favors on all! The justness and severity of this satire cannot be suffi∣ciently applauded.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P:
What vast improvements are daily made in our morals! What an unfortunate dog am I! I came into the world at least half a century too soon; what would I give to be born twenty years hence! Dam'me there will be fine doings then, hey Tom? but I'm afraid our poor little girl
won't have it in her power to profit by these pro∣digious improvements.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Why not?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Oh, when once you hear the name of her partner!

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Who is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: An acquaintance of yours; Only that fat, fusty, shabby, shuffling, money loving, water drinking, mirth-marring, amorous, old huncks, Master Solomon Flint.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: What, he that enjoys, I mean owns, half the farms in the country?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: He, even he!

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Why, he is sixty at least;—what a filthy old goat! But then how does this design suit with his avarice? The girl has no fortune.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: No more than what her talents will procure her.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Why, the poltroon does not mean to profit by them?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Perhaps, if his family should chance to increase; but, I believe, his main motive is the hopes of an heir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: For which he must be indebted to some of his neighbours.—In that point of light, indeed, the matter is not so much amiss; it is impossible she can be fond of the fellow; and it is very hard, with the opportunities that this place will afford, if in less than a month I dont—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: This place! why you don't think he'll trust her here for an hour?

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: How?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Not a moment; the scheme is all settled; the rumbling old family Coach carries her immediately from the church door to his moated, haunted, old house in the country.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Where, besides the Argus himself, she will be watch'd by no less than two brace of his sisters, four as fusty, malicious old maids, as ever were sour'd by solitude, and the neglect of the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: A guard not to be corrupted or cozen'd; why, Sir Christopher, in a Christian country this must not be suffered.—What, a miserable, bat∣ter'd old fellow like him to monopolize such a tempting treasure as her!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: A most diabolical plan!

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Besides, the secluding and immuring a a girl possess'd of her elegant talents is little better than robbing the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Infamous! worse than a rape! but where are the means to prevent it?

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Much might be done, if you would lend us your assistance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Me! of what use can I—and so you rascal you want to employ me again as your pimp.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: My dear Sir Kitt, you take the thing wrong! I only wish you to stand forth, my dear knight, like myself, the protector of innocence and a true friend to the public.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: The public! a fine stalking horse that; but I fear, like other pretenders, Tom, when your own private purpose is serv'd, the poor public will be left in the lurch;—but, however, the girl does deserve to be sav'd; and if I could do any thing not inconsistent with my plan of re∣forming—

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: That was spoke like yourself! upon what terms are you and Flint at present?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Oil and vinegar are not so opposite.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Poultice, you smoke a pipe with him sometimes. Pray who are your party?

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Mynheer Sour Grout, the cue player at billiards; Monsieur De Jersy, the port manufac∣turer; Billy Button, the taylor, and Master Flint and I, most evenings take a wiff at the Chequer.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Are you all in his confidence on this great occasion?

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: We have had a consultation upon most of the measures; but Billy Button is first in his favor, he likes his prescriptions the best.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: From this quarter then we must begin the attack; could not we contrive to convene this illustrious assembly to night?

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: I should think easily enough.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: But before you meet at the Chequer?

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Without doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: My dear Poultice will you undertake the commission?

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: I'll feel their pulses to oblige Sir Chri∣stopher.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: But, Peter, dost really think this rash fool is determined?

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: I believe, Sir Christopher, he is firmly persuaded that nothing will allay this uncommon heat in his blood, but swallowing the pill matri∣monial.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: We must contrive, at least, to take off the gilding, and see what effect that will have on his courage.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Well, Major, unfold what can you mean by this meeting?

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Is it possible you can be at a loss; you who have so long study'd mankind?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Explain.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P:
Can't you conceive what infinite struggles must have been felt by this fellow, before he could muster up courage enough to engage in this dreadful perilous state;—how often have you heard the proverbial puppy affirm, that marriage was fishing for a single eel amongst a barrel of snakes, what infinite odds that you laid hold of
the eel, and then a million to one but he slipp'd through your fingers.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: True, Tom, true.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Can't you then guess what will be his feelings and fears when it comes to the push; dont you think the public opinion, his various doubts of himself and of her, the pride of his family, and the loud claims of avarice, his ruling passion till now, won't prove near an equepoize to his love?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Without doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: At this critical period won't the concur∣ing advice of all his associates, think you, destroy the ballance at once?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Very probable, Tom, I confess.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: As to our engines there is no fear of them; Billy Button you have under your thumb: I'll purchase a pipe of Port from De Jersy; and we are sure of old Sour Grout for a hamper of Hock.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Right, right; but after all, what is to become of the girl? Come Tom, I will have no soul Play shewn to her.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Her real happiness is part of my project.

SP.SPEAKER: Fill.
SP.P: Here be Mynheer Sour Grout and Moun∣seer De Jarsy come.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P:
We will attend them. [Exit Fillup.] Only think, Tom, what a villain you will be to
make me the secret instrument of any more mis∣chief.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Never fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Particularly too, now I am fix'd to reform.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: It would be criminal in the highest de∣gree.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Ah, rot your hypocritical face! I am half afraid, Tom, to trust you; I'll be hang'd if you han't some wicked design yourself on the girl; but, however, I wash my hands of the guilt.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: My dear Knight don't be so squeamish; but the gentlemen within,—stay, who have we here—ah—my old friend Master Button.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Your worship is welcome to town—but where is Sir,—oh: I understood as how your honor had sent for me all in a hurry. I should have brought the patterns before, if I had them. The worst of my enemies can't say but Billy But∣ton is punctual—Here they be, I received them to-night by Wiltshires waggon, that flies in eight days.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: To-morrow, Billy, will do, take a seat. I wanted to talk with you upon another affair—What, I suppose, you are very busy at present?

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Vast busy your honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: This marriage, I reckon, takes up most of your time.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Your honor!

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Miss Linnet, and your old master Flint, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Oh, ay; but the squire don't intend to cut a dash till the spring.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: No, nothing happen'd! I hope, affairs are all fix'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: As a rock; I am sure now it can't fail, because why, I have peremptory orders to scour and new line the coachmans and footman's old frocks; and am, besides, to turn the lace and fresh button the suit his honor had made up twenty years ago, come next Lent, when he was shrieve for the county.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Nay, then it is determined.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Or he would never have gone to such an expence!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Well, Billy, and what is your private opinion, after all, of this match?

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: It is not becoming, your honor knows, for a tradesman, like me, to give his—

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Why not? Don't you think, now Billy, it is a bold undertaking for a man at his time of life?

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Why, to be sure, his honor is a little stricken in years, as a body may say; and take all the care that one can, time, time, will wear the nap from even superfine cloth: Stitches tear, and elbows will out as they say.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: True. And besides, Bill, the bride's a meer baby.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Little better, your honor; but she is a tight bit of stuff, and, I am confident, will turn out well in the wearing. I once had some thoughts, myself, of taking measure of Miss.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Yes, and, to my thinking had made a pretty good progress; because why, at church, of a Sunday, she suffer'd me to look out for her the lessons and the text: and moreover, many a time and oft, we have sung psalms together out of the very same book.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: That was going a good way.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Nay, besides, and more than all this, she has, at this precious minute of time, a pin∣cushion by her side of my own presentation.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Ay, and how came the treaty broke off?

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Why, who should step in, in the nick, but the very Squire himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: I am afraid, Bill, your beauty is a little bit of a jilt?

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: No, your worship, it is all along with her mother, 'cause her great aunt, by her father's side was a clergyman's daughter, she's as prag∣matic and proud as the Pope; so, sorsooth, no∣thing will please her, for Miss, but a bit of quality binding.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P:
I knew the refusal could not come from the girl; for without a compliment, Billy, there
is no comparison between you and the—why you are a pretty, slight, tight, light, nimble and—

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Yes, very nimble and slight, and we are both of a height. Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Why, love has made Billy a poet.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: No, no, quite an accident as I hope to be kiss'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: And your rival is a fusty, foggy, lum∣bering old log.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: For all the world like my goose, plaguy hot and damn'd heavy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Why, Billy blazes to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: And tho' my purse, may-hap, ben't so heavy as his'n, yet I contrives to pay every body their own.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: I dare say.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Ay, and have, besides, two houses in Avon street; and, perhaps, a bit or two of land in a corner.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Oh, the curmudgeonly rogue!

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: And, moreover, if Madam Linnet talks of families, I would have her to know, that I have as powerful relations as well as herself. Why, there's Tommy Button, my uncle's own son, that has an employment under the government.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Ay, Billy, what is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P:
At this very precious minute of time, he's an exciseman at Wapping.—And, besides, there is my cousin, Paul Puff, that kept the great pastry cooks shop in the Strand, now
lives at Brentford, and is made a justice of peace.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: As this is the case, I dont think it will be difficult yet to bring matters to bear.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: If Bill will but follow directions.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: I hope your honor never found me defi∣cient?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: We will instruct you farther within. Major Racket your hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Let me help your—Folks may go farther and fare worse, as they say; why, I have some thoughts, if I can call in my debts, to retire into the country and set up for a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Why not? one meets a great number of them who were never bred to the business.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: I an't much of a mechanic at present, I does but just measure and cut.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: No.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: I don't think that I have sat cross-leg'd for these six years.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: No. And who can tell, your honor, in a few years, if I behaves well, but like cousin Puff, I may get myself put into commmission?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: The worshipful William Button, Esq. It sounds well; and I can tell you, Billy, there have been magistrates made of as bad materials as yourself.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. Mrs. Linnet's House.
DIV3.STAGE: Enter Mrs. LINNET and Miss LINNET.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: YES, Kitty, it is in vain to deny it. I am convinced there is some little, low, paltry passion, lurking in that breast of yours.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Indeed, my dear mother, you wrong me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: Indeed, my dear Miss, but I don't! What else could induce you to reject the addresses of a lover like this? Ten thousand pounds a year! Gads my lise, there is not a lady in town would refuse him, let her rank be ever so—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Not his fortune, that I firmly believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: Well! and who, now-a-days, marries for any thing else? Would you refuse an estate because it happens to be a little encumber'd? You must consider the man, in this case, as a kind of a mortgage.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: But the disproportion of years.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: In your favor, child,—the mortgage will be the sooner remov'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Then, my dear Mother, our minds; how very widely they differ! my nature is liberal and frank, tho' I am but a little remov'd from mediocrity; but his heart, in the very bosom of wealth, is shut to every social sensation.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: And yet, Miss, this heart you have had the happiness to unlock. I hope you don't urge his offers to you as a proof of his passion for money! Why, you forget yourself, Kate; who, in the name of wonder do yo think that you are? What, because you have a baby face, and can bawl a few ballads—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Nay, madam, you know I was never vain of my talents; if they can procure me a de∣cent support, and, in some measure, repay my father and you for their kind cultivation—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: And▪ how long are you sure your talents, as you call them, will serve you?—Are a set of features secure against time; and won't a single sore throat destroy the boasted power of your pipe! But, suppose that should not fail, who can insure you against the whim of the public; will they always continue their favor?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Perhaps not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P:
What must become of you then? Now by this means you are safe, above the reach of ill fortune; besides, child, to put your own in∣terest out of the question, have you no tender feelings for us? Consider, my love, you don't want for good nature; and your consent to this
match, will, in the worst of times, secure a firm and able friend to the family.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: You deceive yourself, indeed, my dear mother: He a friend! I dare believe, the first proof you will find of his friendship, will be, his positive commands to break off all correspondence with every relation I have.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: That's a likely story indeed!—Well, child, I must set your father to work, I find what little weight my arguments have.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Is Mrs. Lynnet within?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs L.
SP.P: Oh, here comes a protectress of yours, Lady Catherine Coldstream; submit the matter to her Ladyship, she can have no views, is well read in the ways of the world, and has your interest sincerely at heart.
SP.STAGE: Enter Lady CATHERINE. This Scotch character was wrote purposely for Mrs. Fearon, a Scotch woman, who was brought by Mr. Foote from Scotland; and she played it exceeding well, being blessed with a pure native accent.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: How is aw wi you Mestress Lynnet, and Mess,—what a dickens is the maiter wi Mess? she seems got quite in the dumps; I thought you were aw ready to jump out of your skens at the bonny prospect afore you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: Indeed I wish your Ladyship would take Kitty to task, for what I can say signifies nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Ah, that's aw wrong, what has been the maiter, Mess Ketty? You ken well enouk, that children owe an implicit concession to their parents; it is nae for bairns to litigate the wull of their friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: Especially, my Lady, in a case where their own happiness is so nearly concerned; there is no persuading her to accept of Mr. Flint's offers.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Gads marcy, Miss, how comes aw this about! donna you think you ha drawn a braw ticket in the lottery of life? donna you ken that the mon is laird of aw the lond in the country.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Your Ladyship knows, that real hap∣piness does not depend upon wealth.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Ah, Miss, but it is a bonny ingre∣dient; donna you think, Mestress Lynnet, the lass has got some other lad in her heed. The Scotch pronounciation for Head.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: Your Ladyship joins in judgment with me. I have charg'd her, but she stoutly denies it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Mess, you munna be bashful; an you'd solicit a cure, your physician mun ken the cause of your malady.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Your Ladyship may believe me, I have no complaint of that kind.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: The lass is obstinate; Mestress Lynnet canna yoursel gi a guess?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: I can't say that I have observ'd. In∣deed, some time ago, I was inclined to believe Mr. Button—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: What yon taylor in Stall Street! eich Mrs. Lynnet, you are aw out in your guess. The lass is o'er weel bred, and o'er soncy, to gi her heart to sic a bourgois as he, Wully Button; na, na, he is na the lad of aw.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: Major Racket, I once thought; but your Ladyship knows his affairs took a different turn.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Ay, Racket! that is another Mons matter: lasses are apt enouk to set their hearts upon scarlet; a cockade, you ken, hath muckle charms wi our sex; yes, yes, yes. Weel Mess, blaws the wund fra that corner?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Does your Ladyship think, to dislike Mr. Flint, it is absolutely necessary to have a pre∣possession for any body else?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Mrs. Lynnet, an you wull withdraw for a while, perhaps Mess may throw off her reserve when there's nobody bye but oursels; a mother, you ken, may be ane o're mony sometimes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: Your Ladyship is most exceedingly kind; doy' hear, Kitty? Mind what her Ladyship says, do, my dear, and be rul'd by your freinds, they are older and wiser than you.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Weel, Mess! what's the cause of aw this? What makes you so averse to the wull of your friends?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Your ladyship knows Mr. Flint.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Ay, unco weel.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Can your ladyship then be at a loss for a cause?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: I canna say maister Flent is quite an Adonis; but wha is it that in matrimony gets aw that they wush? When I intermarried wi Sir Launcelot Cauldstream I was cen sik a straicht spright lass as yoursel; and the onet border∣ing on his grand climacterick. You mun ken Mess, my father was sae unsonsy as to gang out with Charley in forty-five, after which his fidelity was rewarded by France, with a commission that did na bring him in a bawbee, and a pension that he never was paid. A just ridicule on the easy saith of the rebels, and the villany and ingratitude of the French who promoted that re∣bellion.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Infamous ingratitude!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Ay, Mess, but I donna think they will find any mair sic fules in the north.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: I hope not!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: After this you canna think, Mess, there was mickle siller for us poor bairns who were left at hame, so that in troth I was e'en glad to get an establishment and ne'er heeded the disparity between the gude mon and mysel.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Your ladyship gave great proofs of your prudence, but my affairs are not altogether so desperate.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Gods mercy, Mess, I hope you donna make ony comparison between Lady Catharine Cauldstream, wha has the best blood in aw Scot∣land running in her veins!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: I hope your ladyship does not sup∣pose—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: A Lady lineally descended from the great Ossian himsel, and allied to aw the illus∣trious houses abraid and at hame!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: I beg your ladyship—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: And Ketty Linnet! a little wee play∣acor wha gets applauded or hess'd just een as the mobility wulls! To understand this rightly, the reader must know, that players are held, even now, in abhorrence by the generality of the Scotch. Those whose prejudices are obliterated by their connections with us, think and speak more like ratio∣nals, and pay a comedian, of a good moral character, as much respect as any other member of society.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: I am extremely concerned that—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P:
Lookee, Mess, I wull cut the mater very short, you ken well enouk the first nottice that ere I took of you, was on your acting in Allen Ramsay's play of Paty and Roger; ere sine I ha been your fast friend; but an you continue
obstinate, and wull nae sae come, Sae come—A Scotticism for compliance. I shall straight withdraw my protection.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: I shall be extremely unhappy in losing your ladyship's favor.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Mess, that depends on yoursel.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Well, Madam! as a proof how highly I rate it, and how desirous I am of obeying the commands of my parents, it shan't be my fault if their wishes are not accomplish'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: That's aw right my Kitty! gy me a kess! you are the prudent lass I thought you. Love, Mess, is a pastime for boys and green girls, aw stuff, fit for naithing but novels and romances, there is nothing solid, nae stability—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Madam!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: But to fix your fortune at yonce, to get aboon the power of the world, that child is a serious concern.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: With your ladyship's leave?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Mrs. Linnet, you may come in. Your daughter is brought to a proper sense of her duty, and is ready to coincide with your wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: We are infinitely bound to your lady∣ship—this is lucky indeed! Mr. Flint is now be∣low, and begs to be admitted.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Ah, the mon comes just in the nick, shew him up in the instant. [Exit Mrs. Linnet.] Now Ketty, now's your time, donna be shy lass, but throw out aw your attractions, and fix him that he canna gang back.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Madam, I hope to behave—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Gads mercy how the girl trembles and quakes; come pluck up a heart, and consider your aw is at stake.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: I am afraid I shall be hardly able to say a single—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Suppose then you sing—gi him a sang—there is naething moves a love-sick loon mair than a sang—Hark! I hear the lad on the stairs; but let the words be aw melting and saft—the Scots tunes, you ken, are unco pathic.—Sing him the Berks In English it means Broom. of Ender-May, or the Braes Braes are reen Bnks. of Ballendene, or the—[Enter Mr. Flint, and Mrs. Linnet.] Maister Flent, your Servant;—there, Sir, you ken the lass of your heart;—I have laid for you a pretty solid foundation, but as to the edefice you mun e'en erect it yoursel.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Please your ladyship—I'll do my endea∣vours. Madam Linnet, I have made bold to bring you a present,—a small paper of tea in my pocket; you will order the kettle on.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: Oh Sir! you need not have—

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: I was not willing to put you to any ex∣pence. [Exit Mrs. L.] Hum! well, Miss, I un∣derstand here by my Lady, that she, that is, that you, that I, with respect and regard to the—hum; wont you please to be seated?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Sir!—My lover seems as confused as myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: I say, Miss, that, as I was a saying, (here they are seated) your friends here, have, a—spoken to you, all, how and about it?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: About it! about what?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Why about this here business here that I came here about; pray Miss are you fond of the country?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Of the country!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Ay, Miss, because why, I think it is the most prettiest place for your true lovers to live in; something so rural! for my particular I can't see what pleasure pretty Misses can take in galloping to plays and to balls, and such like expensive va∣garies, I hates to be stived up in a room; there is ten times more pastime in fetching walks in the fields, in plucking of daisies—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Hay-making, feeding the poultry, and milking the cows.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Right Miss!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: It must be owned they are pretty em∣ployments for ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Yes; for as my mother used to say, who between ourselves was a notable housewife,

Q.L: May live to bite on the bridle!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: What a happiness to have been bred under so prudent a parent!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Ay, Miss, you will have reason to say so; for her maxims have put many a pretty pound in my pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: How does that concern me?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Because why as the saying is,

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Sir, you are very obliging.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: I can tell you such offers are not every day to be met with; only think, Miss, to have victuals and drink constantly found you without cost or care on your side,—especially too now meat is so dear. This was introduced at the time of raising the price of meat.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Considerations by no means to be slighted.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Moreover, and that you may live and ap∣pear like my wife, I fully and wholly intends to keep you a coach!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Indeed!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P:
Yes, and you shall command the horses whenever you please,—unless during the harvest, and when they are employed in ploughing and
carting;—because why, the main chance must be minded you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: True, true.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Tho' I don't think you will be vastly fond of coaching it about;—for why, we are off of the turnpike, and the roads are deadly deep about we.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: What, you intend to reside in the country then?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Without doubt, for then Miss I shall be sure to have you all to myself!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: An affectionate motive; but even in this happy state, where the most perfect union prevails, some folitary hours will intrude, and the time hang now and then heavily on our hands.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: What, in the country, my dear Miss! not a minute, you will find all pastime and jollity there! for Miss, what with minding the dairy, dunning the tenants, scolding the servants, nursing the children, preserving and pickling, mending and making, roasting, boiling, and baking, you wont have a moment to spare,—you will be merry and happy as the days they are long!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: I am afraid the days will be hardly long enough to execute so extensive a plan of enjoy∣ment!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Never you fear; besides, I am told, Miss, you write an exceeding pretty, tolerable, good hand—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Pretty well, I believe.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P:
Then, Miss, there is more pleasure in store, I'll make you my clerk as a justice of peace, that
you may share sixpence out of every warrant to buy you any little thing you may want. The person here aim'd at, is a certain justice, whose Lady serves him in capacity of clerk, and of course purloins the perquisites.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: That is finely imagin'd!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: And then, Miss, at the end of the year what a comfort, after all this pleasure, to find oneself in pocket beside!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: True, Sir! As your enjoyments are chiefly domestic, I presume you have contriv'd to make home as convenient as can be; you have, Sir, good gardens no doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Gardens! Ay, ay; Why, Miss, before the great parlour window there grows a couple of yews as tall as a mast, and as thick as a steeple, and the boughs cast so delightful a shade, that you can't see your hand in any part of the room!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: A most delicate gloom!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: And then there constantly roostes in the trees, a curious couple of owls, which I wont suf∣fer our folks to disturb, as they made so rural a noise in the night.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: A most charming duet!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: And besides, Miss, they pay for their lodg∣ings, as they are counted very good mousers you know.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: True! but within doors, your mansion is capacious, and—

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Capacious! yes, yes, capacious enough! you may stretch your legs without crossing the thres∣hold—in the winter you may walk till you are warm, without wanting a fire. Why we go up stairs and down into every room of the house!—to be sure, at present, it is a little out of repair; not that it rains in, where the casements are whole, at above five or six places.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Your prospects are pleasing?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: From off the top of the leads; for why, I have boarded up most of the windows in order to avoid paying the tax; but to my thinking, our bedchamber, Miss, is the most pleasantest part of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Oh, Sir, you are very polite!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: No, Miss, it is not for that; but you must know, Miss, that there is a large bow-window facing the East, that does finely for drying of herbs; it is hung round with hatchments of all the folks that have died in the family; and then the pidgeon-house is over our heads.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: The Pidgeon-house!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Yes; and there every morning we shall be waked at day break with their murmuring, cooing, and courting, that will make it as pleasant and fine as can be.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P:
Ravishing! Well, Sir, it must be con∣fessed you have given me a most bewitching pic∣ture of pastoral life; your place is a perfect
arcadia; but I am afraid half the charms are de∣rived from the painter's flattering pencil.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Not heighten'd a bit, as yourself shall be judge; and then, as to company, Miss, you may have plenty of that whenever you will, for we have as pretty a neighbourhood as a body can wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Really!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: There is the widow Kilderkin, who keeps the Adam and Eve, at the end of the town, quite an agreeable body! indeed the death of her hus∣band has drove the poor woman to tipple a bit;—farmer Dobbins's daughter, and doctor Surplice, our curate, and his wife, a vast conversible wo∣man,—if she was not altogether so deaf.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: A very sociable set! Why Sir, plac'd in this paradise, there is nothing left you to wish.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Yes, Miss, but there is—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Ay, what can that be?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: The very same that our grandpapa Adam had, to have a beautiful Eve by my side, (both rising) Would the lovely Linnet permit me to lead her to that bower, nothing loath—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Oh, excess of gallantry!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Would her sweet breath but deign to kin∣dle, and blow up my hopes.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Oh, Mr. Flint, I must not suffer this for your sake; a person of your importance and rank!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: A young Miss of your great merit and beauty—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: A gentleman so accomplished and rich!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Whose perfections are not only the talk of the Bath, but of Bristol and Gloucester, and the whole country round!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Oh, Mr. Flint, this is too—

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Her goodness, her grace, her duty, her decency, wisdom and wit, her shape, slimness and size, with her lovely black eyes, so elegant, en∣gaging, alluring, perfuming, so modest, so pru∣dent, so pious, and if I am rightly informed, Miss, you have a sweet pretty pipe.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: This is such a profusion of—

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Permit me, Miss, to solicit a specimen of your seraphic cherubimical voice.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Why, Sir, as your extravagant com∣pliments have left me nothing to say, I think the best thing I can do is to sing.

LG.HEAD: The Birks of Endermay; To a Scotch Tune.

L.HI: The smiling morn, the breathing spring,
Invite the tuneful birds to sing:
And while they warble from each spray,
Like them improve the hour that flies;
And, in soft raptures, waste the day,

LG.L: Among the Birks of Endermay. Only this one verse of the song was sung.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Enchanting, ravishing sounds! Not the Nine Muses themselves, nor Mrs. Baddely Hinting at the Praise Mrs. Baddely so deservedly ac∣quired in the song of Sweet Willy O! is equal to you!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Oh fie, Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: May I flatter myself that the words of that song were directed to me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Should I make such a confession I should ill deserve the charecter you have been pleased to bestow.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Come, come, Maister Flent, set your heart at rest, lasses are apt to be modest and shy,—then take her answer frae me, prepare the minister and aw the rest of the taickle, and you'll find us ready to gang to kirk in the morning—

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Miss, may I rely on what her ladyships says?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Gads mercy! I think the mon's be∣witch'd,—that he wonna take a woman of quali∣ty's word for sic a trifling thing as a wife!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Your ladyship will impute it all to my hopes, and my doubts, and my fears—then I may direct∣ly set about getting the needful?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Gang your gait as fast as you list—

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Lord bless me I have such a head—I had like to have forgot—my joys and my hopes were—I have put up a few presents, if Miss will deign to accept—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: That's aw right—as matters now stand there is nae harm in her accepting of presents frae you.—Maister Flent, you may produce.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: It's a hard matter to get any thing out of my purse; here's first and foremost a Porto Bello pocket-piece of Admirable Vernon on one side, and six men of war only, on full sail, on t'other.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Yes, yes, yes, it's a curious medal∣lion
SP.STAGE: (presenting it to Lady C. who gives it to Miss L.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Secondly, Here's a queen Ann's half crown, as fresh as out of the Mint. I could have had two shillings and seven-pence halfpenny for it.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Ay, it's in very fine preservation,

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Thirdly, Here are a pair of mourning rings,—that which was left me by my aunt Botherem, might, I should think, do very well for the ap∣proaching happy occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: How! a mourning ring!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: No, my lady, not because of the mourning; but on account of the motto, it's so pretty and apt and pat.

SP.SPEAKER: Fady C.
SP.P: Ay! What is it Mr. Flent?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: True till death—
Shall stop my breath.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Aich, Mess, it contains muckle mora∣lity

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P:
And, fourthly and lastly; if I have not for∣got it, (searching his pocket) a silver coral and
bells, (pulling it out) with only a bit of the coral broke off when I was cutting my grinders (whist∣ling) it has a pretty sound. It was given me by my god-father Slingsby. I hope, Miss, it will come in use again before the year comes about.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Nae doubt, nae doubt, leave that mai∣ter to us. I warrant we'll impede the faimily of the Flents frae fawing into oblivion.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Do you think we shall? I shall be glad of that however, if its only to get a son to enjoy my estate: for, at present there is not a person in the world I care a farthing about.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Make nae doubt; but Mr. Flent, you'd better gang your gait and prepare the tackle.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: I'll get the needful directly.—My Lady your very obedient, most humble, and very—Miss, your ever admiring, and transported—Oh Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: A soncy lad this Maister Flent.—You see, Mess, he has a meaning in aw that he does—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Might I be permitted to alter your Ladyship's words, I should rather say, a meanness in all that he does.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Its nae muckle maiter what the mon is at present.: In a little time you may mould him to any thing that you list.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P:
I am afraid he is not made of such pliant materials; however, the dye is cast and I
cannot retreat. But suppose, my Lady, he should refuse to—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: You ken, Mess, that this treaty was begun under my mediation; and gin he should dare to draw back, Lady Catherine Cauldstream would soon find means to punish his perfidy. Come awa Mess.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE 1. The Bear Inn.
DIV3.STAGE: Sir CHRISTOPHER CRIPPLE, SOUR GROUT, DE JARSEY, MAJOR RACKET, and POULTICE, discovered at Table, with wine, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: WE must take care that Flint does not surprise us, for the scoundrel is very suspicious.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: There is no danger of that; I lodg'd him safely at Linnet's; Button stands centry at the end of the street, so that we shall be instantly ap∣prized of every motion he makes.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Well manag'd, my Major.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Yes, yes, the cunning young dog knows very well what he's about.

SP.SPEAKER: Sour. G.
SP.P: Upon my vord, Major Racket, has de very fine disposition to make a figure at de head of de Army, five or six German Campaigns vill—Ah, ah, dat is de best school in de vorld for make de var.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Five or six German campaigns!

SP.SPEAKER: Sow. G.
SP.P: Ay, Chevalie; vat you say to dat?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Oh, Mynheer, nothing at all; a German war, for ought I know, may be a very good school, but it is a damn'd expensive education for us! There is so much truth and justice in this remark, that it is sufficient of itself to destroy the political maxim of Ame∣rica's being conquered in Germany.

SP.SPEAKER: De J.
SP.P: Cet vrai Chevalier, dat is al! true, cet païs la, dat place is the grave for the Frenchman, and de fine English guinea, diable m'eporte. Our successes in the last German war, great and glorious as they were, were very inadequate to the millions that were sunk in maintaining it.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: True, Monsieur, but our guineas are rather worse off than your men, for they stand no chance of rising again.

SP.SPEAKER: De J.
SP.P: Ha! ha! dat is very well, le Chevalier have beaucoup d'Esprit, great deal of wit ma¦foy.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: And you have a great deal of sincerity, ma foy

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: I think the Knight is in luck; but don't let us lose sight of our subject, You, gentle∣men, are all perfect in the several parts you are to play?

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Ay, ay.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: You Mynheer Sour Grout.—

SP.SPEAKER: Sour. G.
SP.P: I understand; I will pique his honor, de pride of his famille.—The reader must understand, that notwithstanding the natural haughtiness of a German, it is against their law for certain ranks in Germany to degrade the dignity of their ancestors by an alliance with a person of an inferior family.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Right,—Poultice.—

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: I will alarm him on the side of his health.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Next to his money, the thing in the world he most minds.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: You, De Jarsey, and Button, will em∣ploy all your eloquence on the prudential side of the—Oh, De Jarsy, here's the draft for the pipe of port that I purchas'd.—

SP.SPEAKER: De J.
SP.P: Dat is right.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: The only receipt in the world to ge bawds, burroughs, or Frenchmen: Scarce any observation is necessary to justify the truth of this satirical climax. Oh, here Billy comes. [Enter Button.] Well, Billy, what news?

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: I am vast afraid, as how all matters are concluded at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Ay, prithee, why so?

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Because why, in ten minutes after you went, out bolted the Squire, and hurry scurry'd away to Layer Latitats, who you know arrestes tenants, and does all his concarns.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: True! Well, Billy.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: I suppose to give him orders about draw∣ing the writings.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Not unlikely; but you think Flint will come to the club?

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: There is no manner of doubt; because why, he hollo'd to me from over the way, what, Billy, I suppose you are bound to the Bear; well, boy, I shall be hard at your heels; and he seem'd in prodigious vast spirits.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: I am mistaken if we don't lower them a little. Well, gentlemen, the time of action draws nigh, and it is time, Knight, for us to decamp.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: When you will Major;

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: I think, Sir Christopher, you lodge in the same house with the Linnets.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Just over their heads.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Then thither we'll go, ten to one if our plot operates as I expect, but the hero will return to their house.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Most likely.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: We are come to a crisis, and the catas∣trophe of our piece can't be very far off.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: I wish, like other plays, it don't end in a marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Then I shall be most confoundly bit; but come Knight.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P:
Rot you, I do as sast as I can.—I can't think, Major Racket, what the deuce makes you
so warm in this business, there is certainly some∣thing at bottom that I don't comprehend; but do Major have pity upon the poor girl, upon my soul she is a sweet little Syren, so innocent—and,

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Poo, poo, don't be absurd, I thought that matter had been fully explain'd, this, Knight, is no time to look back; but suppose now I should have a little mischief in hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: How, of what kind?

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Be innocent of the knowledge, dearest Knight, till thou applaud the deed.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: It is very extraordinary, Major Racket, if you are determin'd to make the devil a visit, that you can't pay it alone; or if you must have com∣pany, what a pox makes you always think of fix∣ing on me?

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Heyday! what in the vapors again? we must have t'other sneaker of punch.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: You are mistaken,—that won't have power to change the state of my mind, my re∣solves are too firm.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: And who wishes to break them? I only ask your assistance to-night, and your resormation you recollect does not begin till to-morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: That's true indeed; but no human power shall prevail on me to put off any longer than to∣morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Or the next day at sarthest.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: May I be damn'd if I do. The irresolution of a valetudinarian could not be possi∣bly painted in stronger colours than by this jumble of swear∣ing and reforming.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Come, lads, light your pipes, which of us shall be first to attack.—Billy—

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Won't it be rather too bold for me to begin?

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Then let us leave it to chance—hush!—I hear him lumbering in,—compose your looks, and let his reception be solemn and grave.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Leave that chair for him.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Ah, how fares it my lads! Well, boys, matters are settled at last, the little Kate has com∣plied, and to-morrow is fix'd for the day.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: You have settled it then?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: As firm as a rock.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: So you can't retreat if you would?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Retreat! I have no such design.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: You han't?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: No, to be sure, you great fool! What the deuce would Poultice be at?

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Nay, then, neighbours, what we have been saying will just signify nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Saying! why you have not heard? that is, nobody has—

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: No, nothing very material, only—but as the matter is carried so far—

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: So far! Why I hope you have not found out any flaw; Kitty has not.—

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: No, no, no, nothing of that; no upon my word I believe a very modest, prudent, pious, good girl, neighbours—

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: No manner of doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Well then! but what a plague is the mean∣ing of this, you all look as silent and glum, why can't you speak up with a pox?

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Why, Squire, as we all are your fix'd friends, we have been canvassing the matter amongst us.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: You have!

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Marriage, you know very well, is no trifling affair, too much caution and care can't be us'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: That I firmly believe, which has made me defer it so long.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Pray lend me your hand; (feeling his pulse;) how is the state of your health; do you find yourself hearty and stout. The manner of conducting this scene was reckon'd a master stroke of dramatical ingenuity.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: I think so; that is I, you han't observ'd any bad symptoms of late?

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: No, but you us'd to have pains flying about you.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Formerly, but since I have fixed my gout to a fit they are gone; that, indeed, lays me up for four or five months in a year.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: A pretty long spill, and in such a case do you think now that marriage—

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: The most best receipt in the world; why that, man, was one of my motives, wives you know are allowed to make very good nurses.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: That, indeed.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Ay, and then they are always at hand; and besides they don't cost one a farthing.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: True, true, why you look very jolly and stout—does he not.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Jolly and stout!

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Exceedingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: And yet he can't be less than,—let me see—was not you under old Syntaxs, at Wells?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: I left the school the year he died.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: That must be a good forty years since.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Come sheep-shearing next, Mr. Poultice.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Then, Squire, you are hard upon sixty?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Not far away, Master Poultice.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: And Miss Linnet, sixteen! you are a bold man! not but there are instances, tho' they are not very common indeed, where men have sur∣vived many years such disproportionate matches.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Surviv'd! and why should they not?

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: But then their stamina must be prodi∣giously strong.

SP.SPEAKER: Flint.
SP.P: Stamina!

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Let us see, Button, there was doctor Do∣tage who married the Devonshire girl, he liv'd a matter of—

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: No, no, he dropp'd off in six months.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: True, true, I had forgot—

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Lord have mercy!

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Indeed an old master of mine, Sir Harry O Tuff, is alive, and walks about to this day.—

SP.SPEAKER: Poult.
SP.P: Ay, but you forget where Sir Harry was born, and how soon his lady eloped. A satire on our modern fashionable elopements.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: O, in the honey moon with captain Pike of the guards, I minds it full well.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: That indeed alters the case. Well, well, but, Billy, you are not serious in this, you don't think there is any danger of death?

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: As to the matter of death the Doctor knows better than I, because why, that's in his way; but I shall never forget Colonel Crazy, one of the best customers that ever I—I never think of him without dropping a tear.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Why, what was the matter with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Married Lady Barbara Bounce, as it might be, on the Monday at midnight.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Well!

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: But never more saw the sweet face of the sun!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: What did he die! This is a known fact—The gentleman expired in the night, and was found dead by his Lady next morning,—the shock was so great that she continues to this day bercft of her senses.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Within an hour after throwing the stock∣ing.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Good Lord! That was dreadful indeed! Of what age might he be?

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: About your time of life, Squire.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: That is vastly alarming! Lord Bless me, Billy, I am all of a tremble!

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Ay, truly, it behoves you, Squire, to consider what you are about.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: True, Billy, true.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Then what a world of money must go in running backwards and forwards to town and jaunting to see all the fine sights in the place.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: I shan't take her to many of them; perhaps I may shew her the parliament houses, and plays, and Boodles and Bedlam, and my Lord Mayor and the Lions. It was wrote about the Time of the Lord Mayor's confinement in the Tower.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Then the vast heap of fine cloaths you must make up!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: What occasion for that?

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: As you ar'n't known, there is no doing without; beeause why, every body passes there for what they appear.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Right, Billy; but I believe I have found out a way to do that pretty cheap.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Which way is that Squire?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: You have seen the minister that's come to tack us together?

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: I have; is he a fine man in the pulpit?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: He don't care much to meddle with preach∣ing and praying; but he is a prodigious patriot, and a great politician to boot. The Rev. Mr. Horne.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Ay, and has left behind him, at Paris, a choice collection of curious rich cloaths, which he has promised to sell me a penn'orth. Alluding to the well known story of a trunk full of cloaths left at Paris by Mr. H. in which were so many dif∣ferent suits, that the parson could be a captain one day and a quaker the next; the third a petite maitre, and the fourth a parson again; and a physician with the addition of a sword.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Pooh! What Billy talks of are trifles to the evils you are too expect: to have a young girl breaking in upon all your old ways; your afternoon's nap interrupted, and perhaps not suf∣fered to take your pipe of a night.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: No!

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: All your former friends forbidden your house.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: The fewer come in the less will go out; I shan't be very sorry for that.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: To make room for her own numerous clan, who after all won't even vouchsafe you a nod.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Not a soul of them shall enter the doors.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: A brood of babes at your board, whose fathers she wou'd not, herself, find it easy to name.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: To prevent that I'll lock her up in a room.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: The King's Bench will break open your door.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Then I'll turn her out of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: And her debts will throw you into a jail.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Who told you so?

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: A dozen of proctors.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Then I will hang myself out of the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: By which she will become possessed of her jointure, and her creditors foreclose your estate.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: O Lord! What a miserable poor toad is a a husband, whose misfortunes not even death itself can relieve!

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Think of that, Squire, before it is too late.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Well, but friends, neighbours, what the deuce can I do! Are you all of a mind?

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: All.

SP.SPEAKER: De J.
SP.P: Dere is no question at all: vat, a garcon of your ancien famille to take up with a pauvre petite bourgoise!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Does that never happen in the French country Mounseer?

SP.SPEAKER: De J.
SP.P: Never but when Monsieur De Baron is very great Beggar, and la Bourgoise has domn'd deal de guinea.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: O Lord! that is none of our case, for she is as poor as a church-mouse, and 'tis I have the domn'd deal de guinea. Mynheer Sour Grout, do your people never make up such matches.

SP.SPEAKER: Sour G.
SP.P: Never! never! What a German dis∣honor his stocks! I never was known such a ding. Why, Maister Flint, should Mistress Ly∣net bring you de children for de ten generation to come, they could not be chose de Channon of Strabourgh.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: No! O Lord, what a parcel of poor miserable devils they would be!

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: So, Squire, you see, take it which way you will, what dreadful danger you shun!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: I do! I do!

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Loss of friends!

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Pipe and afternoon's nap!

SP.SPEAKER: Sour G.
SP.P: Your familly gone to de dogs!

SP.SPEAKER: De J.
SP.P: Your peace of mind to de devil!

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Your health!

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Your wealth!

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Plate, money, and manors!

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Your, your—

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Enough, enough! Dear neighbours, enough! I feel, I feel it too well! Lord of mercy what a miserable scrape am I in! And here too, not an hour ago, it has cost me the Lord knows what in making her presents!

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Never mind that, you had better part with half you are worth in the world!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: True, true; well then I'll go and break off all matters this minute.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: The wisest thing you can do.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: The sooner the better, Squire.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: No doubt, no doubt, in the—
Billy Button!

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Squire,

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: She is a vast pretty girl! I should be hear∣tily sorry to loose her. Dos't think one could not get her on easier terms than marriage?

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: It is but trying however.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: To tell truth, Billy, I have always had that in my head. I have thought of a project that will answer my purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Ay, Squire, what is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: I wont tell; Billy, if I should get her con∣sent, and you will take her off my hands when I begin to grow tired, I will settle ten pounds a-year upon you for both of your lives!

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Without paying the taxes?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: That matter we will talk of hereafter, little Billy.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: So, so, we have settled this business however.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: No more thoughts of his taking a wife.

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: He would sooner be tied to a gibbet. But, Billey, step after him;—they will let you in at Sir Christopher Cripples; observe all that passes, and bring us, Bill, a faithful account.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: I will, I will; but where shall you be?

SP.SPEAKER: Poul.
SP.P: Above, in the Phenix, we will not stir out of the house; but be very exact.

SP.SPEAKER: Bill.
SP.P: Never fear.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Heigh ho! What a sacrifice am I going to make; but it is the will of those who have a right to all my obedience, and to that will I submit. (Loud knocking at the door.) Bless me! who can that be at this time of night? Our friends may err, and projects, the most pru∣dentially pointed, may miss of their aim; but age and experience demand respect and attention, and the undoubted kindness of our parents designs claims on our part, at least a grateful and ready compliance.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Nancy, who was that at the door?

SP.SPEAKER: Nancy.
SP.P: Mr. Flint, Miss, begs the favor of speaking five words.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: I was in hopes to have had this night, at least, to myself. Where is my mother?

SP.SPEAKER: Nancy.
SP.P: In the next room with lady Catherine, consulting about your cloaths for the morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: He is here. Very well, you may go.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Thank you Mrs. Nancy.—I'll give you the first crooked six-pence I get. [Exit Nancy.] She is alone as I wish'd. Miss, I beg pardon for in∣truding at this time of night; but—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: You can't wonder that I desire to enjoy your good company every minute I can.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Those minutes, a short space will, Mr. Flint, place in your own power; if, till then, you had permitted me to—

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Right, Miss, but to say truth, I wanted to have a little serious talk with you—all how and about it. I think, Miss, you agree, if we marry, to go off to the country directly?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: If we marry! Is it then a matter of doubt?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Why, I will tell you Miss, with regard to myself, you know, I am one of the most antient∣est families all the country round!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Without doubt.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: And as to money and land, in these parts, I believe few people can match me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Perhaps not.

SP.SPEAKER: Flint.
SP.P: And as to yourself, I don't speak in a disparaging way; your friends are but low folks, and your fortune just nothing at all.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: True, Sir; but this is no new disco∣very, you knew this before.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Hear me out, Miss. Now as I brings all these good things on my side, and you have no∣thing to give in return but your love, I ought to be pretty certain of the possession of that.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: I hope the properly discharging all the duties of that condition, which I am shortly to owe to your favor, will give you convincing proofs of my gratitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Pshaw! your gratitude, Miss! but I talk of your love; and of that, if I marry, I must have plain and positive proofs.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Proofs! of what kind?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: There is but one that I know.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: What is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Flint.
SP.P: Can't you guess?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Not I on my word!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Why, lookee, Miss, I am a man of vast prodigious delicacy, and my delicacy requires, that you steal away with me directly to my lodg∣ings.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Your lodgings!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: There stay the whole night, and in the morning, when my delicacy is satisfied, we'll march away to the abbey and be married.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: In short, Miss, I must have this proof of your love; or not a syllable more of the marriage.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Give me patience!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Come, Miss, we have not a minute to lose; the coast is clear, and should any body come in, you will put it out of my power to do what I de∣sign.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Power! Hands off Mr. Flint.—Power! I promise you, Sir, you never shall have me in your power—

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: How, Miss!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Despicable Wretch! from what part of my character could your vanity derive a hope, that I would submit to your infamous purpose?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Lord Miss, don't be in such a—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: To put principle out of the question; not a creature, who has the least tincture of pride, could fall a victim to such a comtemptible wretch!

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Why, but Miss,—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss. L.
SP.P: It is true, in compliance with the earnest request of my friends, I had consented to sacrifice my peace to their pleasure; and tho' reluctant would have given you my hand—

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: And a vast pretty present I should have had.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: What motive, but obedience to them, could I have had in forming an union with you! Did you think I was struck with your personal merit—

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Why not!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Or that the sordidness of your mind and manners could tempt me?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Really, Miss, this is carrying the—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
