SP.P: You have wealth, I confess, but where would have been the advantage to me! As a reward for becoming your drudge, I might, per∣haps, have received a scanty subsistence; but I can never suppose you would grant the free use of that to your wife, which your meanness has de∣nied to yourself.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: So, so, so,—you'll alarm the whole house!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: The whole house! The whole town shall be acquainted with—

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: So let them and they will—A pretty ex∣travagant house I am got into—Two candles a burning!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Sure the greatest misfortune that po∣verty brings in its train, is the subjecting us to the insults of wretches, like this, who have no other merit than what their money bestow.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: What a damnable vixen!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Go, Sir, leave the house; I am asham'd you have had the power to move me: and never more let me be shock'd with your appearance.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: What, I have moved you, have I? Why then you shall be even with me, and so you shall move me.
SP.STAGE: (As he is going Lady Coldstream speaks without.)

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: How's aw wi you withen?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: O Lord! here's the Scotch woman again!
SP.STAGE: Enter Lady CATHERINE COLDSTREAM and Mrs. LINNET.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Gad's marcy! what's the maiter wi Mess! I hope Maister Flent it is no you wha ha set her a wailing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs L.
SP.P: Kitty! My love! What's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: A modest proposal of that gentleman's making.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Of what kind, Mess.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Only, this moment, to quit my father and you, and take up my lodging with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: To night! Ay, that's quite out of the order of things—That's ne'er done, Maister Flent, till after the ceremony of the nuptials are said.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Is'nt it? Then it never will be done.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: How!
SP.STAGE: Enter Sir CHRISTOPHER, led in by Major RACKET and BILLY BUTTON.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: We beg pardon for taking the liberty to come in; but we were afraid some accident had happened to Miss—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: There has Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Of what nature, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: That worthy gentleman there, under pretence of friendship to us, and honorable views on my daughter, has hatch'd a most treacherous design to ineitably ruin my child!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: What he! Flint?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: Even he.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: An impudent son of a—Billy, lead me up that I may take a peep at the puppy. Your servant young gentleman! What, is this true that we hear? A sweet swain this to tempt a virgin to him! Why, old nick has made a little mistake here: he us'd to be a little more expert in his angling; for what female on earth could be found to catch at this bait?

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Haud ye, haud ye, Sir Christopher, let Maister Flent and I ha a short conference on the occasion. I suppose, Maister Flent, you per∣severe to gang wi Mess to kirk i'the morning?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: I'the morning! no, nor the evening nei∣ther.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Gad's marcy! do you refuse to raitisy the preliminaries?

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: I don't say that neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir C.
SP.P: Then name the time in which you will fulfil them: a week.—

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: A fortnight.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. L.
SP.P: A month.

SP.SPEAKER: Flint.
SP.P: I won't be bound down to no time.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: A rascally evasion of his to avoid an ac∣tion at law.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir C.
SP.P: But perhaps he may be disappointed in that.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: Weel, but Maister Flent, are you wul∣ling to mack Mess a pecuniary acknowledgment for the domage.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: I have done her no domage, and I'll make no acknowledgment.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Twelve honest men of your country may happen to differ in judgment.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Let her try if she will.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir C.
SP.P: And I promise you she shan't be to seek for the means.

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: If you be na asraid of the laws, ha you na sense of shame?

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: He sense of shame!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss C.
SP.P:
Gads wull! it shall come to the proof; you mun ken, gudefolks, at Edinburgh laist wenter, I got acquaint with maister Fett, the
play acor, I wull get him to bring the filthy loon on the stage. The Winter before this play made its appearance, Mr. Foote had the management of, and played at the Theatre Royal, Edinburgh.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: And so expose him to the contempt of the world he so richly deseves it.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Ay, he may write, you may rail, and the people may hiss, what care I? I have that at home that will keep up my spirits!

SP.SPEAKER: Lady C.
SP.P: At hame!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: The wretch means his money.

SP.SPEAKER: Fl.
SP.P: Money! And what better friend can any man have? Tell me the place where its influence fails—Ask that gentleman there, how he got his cockade: Money! I know it's worth, and there∣fore can't too carefully keep it: Even now, I have a proof of its value; for it protects me from the designs of that squeamish giddy headed girl, and the weak efforts of your impotent malice—Call me forth to your courts when you please, I have that shall procure me able defenders,—and good wit∣nesses too, if they are wanted. So you may all go to the devil together.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: You had better let him alone, it will an∣swer no end; what a damnable dog is a miser!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P:
Much worse than a robber; that poor devil only pilfers from Peter or Paul, and the mo∣ney is scattered as soon as received; but the wretch
who accumulates for the sake of secreting, anni∣hilates what was intended for the use of the world, and is a robber of the whole human race!

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: And himself too into the bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: For all the world like a magpye, he steals for the mere pleasure of hiding.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Well observ'd little Billy!

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Why he wanted to bring me into his plot; yes, he did, he made proposials for me to marry Miss after his delicacy was satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: How!

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: But he was out in his man; let him give his cast cloaths to his coachman;—Billy Button can afford a new suit of his own.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: I don't doubt it.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Fellow! I am almost resolved never to set another stitch for him as long as I live.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Right, Button, right! but where is Miss Kitty? Come hither my chicken; saith I am hear∣tily glad you are rid of this scoundrel; and if such a cripled old fellow as me was worthy your notice; but hold Kate there is another chap I must guard you against.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Another, Sir! who?

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Why this gentleman here.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Me!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Ay, you! Come, come, Major, don't think you can impose upon a cunning old sports∣man like me.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Upon my soul, Sir Christopher, you real∣ly make me blush at your—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Oh, you are devilish modest I know; but to come to the trial at once: I have some reason to believe, Major, you are fond of this girl, and that her want of fortune mayn't plead your excuse, take her, and with her five thou∣sand good guineas into the bargain.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: Sir!

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: And expect another good spill, you young dog, when Monsieur Le Fevre set me free of the gout.

SP.SPEAKER: Butt.
SP.P: Please your worship, I'll accept her with half.
SP.STAGE: (Here Button runs to Sir Christopher, and the Major puts him out of the room.)

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: How, Sir, shall I acknowledge this goodness.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: By saying nothing about it. Well, Sir, we wait for your answer.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: I think the lady ought first to be con∣sulted, I should be sorry a fresh persecution should follow so fast on the heels of—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Come, come, no trifling, your resolu∣tion at once.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: I receive then, Sir, your offer with plea∣sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Miss!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: Hold, Sir! there is a little account to be first settled between this gentleman, and an old acquaintance of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Ch.
SP.P: Who?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: The Major can guess,—the unhappy Miss Prim.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Sh.
SP.P: You see, Major, your old sins are ri∣sing in judgment.

SP.SPEAKER: Rack.
SP.P: I believe, Madam, I can satisfy you that—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss L.
SP.P: I shan't give you the trouble; but let me, gentlemen, return you all my most grateful ful acknowledgments for your kind intentions to∣wards me. I know your generous motive, and feel its value, I hope, as I ought; but might I be permitted to choose, I should beg to remain in the station I am; my little talents have hitherto re∣ceiv'd the public protection, nor whilst I continue to deserve, am I the least afraid of losing my pa∣trons!

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE,
DIV1.P: CONFIDING in the justice of the place, To you, the MAID OF BATH, submits her case.
DIV1.L: Wrong'd and defeated of three several spouses,
She lays her damage at,—nine full houses!
Well, Sirs, you've heard the parties pro and con:
Do the pro's carry it? Shall the suit go on?
Speak hearts for us, to them we make appeal:
Tell us not what you think, but what you feel.
For as our Author takes satiric aim,
He seldom starts, but seizes on the game.
So on a ramble late one starry night,
With Don Asmodeo his familiar sprite;
Soaring in air his ready pen he drew,
And dash'd the glowing satire as he flew.
And in these rank, luxuriant days, there needs
Some strong, bold hand, to pluck the noxious weeds;
The rake of sixty, crippl'd hand and knee,
Who sins on claret! and repents on tea!
The witless Macaroni who purloins
A few cant words, which some pert gambler coins!
The undomestic Amazonian dame,
Staunch to her coteric in despight of shame!
These are the objects of our poet's plan;
But most, that monster, an unfeeling man!
When such a foe provokes him to the fight,
Tho' maim'd, out sallies, the puissant knight!
Like With'rington maintains the glorious strife,
And only yields his laurels with his life!
